THE ALUMNI BANQUET
The annual alumni banquet of
1910, held on the evening of the
22nd, at the Hotel Beivedeit has
c.orne and gone,as far as the beautiful
ecorations and flowers and delicious menu, provided by the Committee, Messrs. Williams, Ogden and
Abercrombie, are L oncerned, and
many were the expressions of appreciation and pleasure heard from
the nearly two hundred alumni and
their guests assembled together on
that delightful occasion.
But in the spirit of fellowship
manifested and engendered and in
the feeling of enthusiasm created by
the eloquent addresses, the banquet
of 1910 will always live among those
fortunate enough to be present. How
one feels the inspiration of association, at a gattiering like this! How
forcibly .do such reunions impress up'On one the inestimable value of daily
intercourse among the students, the
living together within the same
Walls, the sleeping under the same
roofs! Only under such conditions
With such relations of daily life can
the influence of our Alma Mater be
forcibly realized; and for the accomplishment of this end we have
That
but one goal—Homewood.
University
the
the establishment of
Upon this beautiful site is essential
znd vital to its welfare is undisputed. Some additional funds will be
necessary actually to move, but this
task accomplished and the University once there, Johns Hopkins will
be the recipient of ample endowments, ever increasing in number,
With which to pursue her splendid
Work in the field of education.
Many distinguished guests honored the alumni by their presence.
Among them were, his Excellency,
the German Ambassador, Count
Bernstoff, and Dr. Robert Falconer,
President of Toronto University,the
nrasor of the day at the morning exercises in McCoy Hall. His Excellency in his admirable address dwelt
O n the feeling of good fellowship and
friendly relations existing between
the German Empire aryl this country,
expressed the belief that the intercourse between the scientists and the
scholars of the Universities of the
two countries, Germany and the
Pnited States, were potent factors
In arousing and cementing such
feelings of good will. He spoke
the value
emphasis of
With
country
a
to
university
a
of
and pointed out how his government
turned to the different professors in
the various German universities for

Baltimore, Md., March 7, 1910.
the solution of many problems and
for settlement of the disturbing
questions of the day. The address
of Count Bernstoff was eloquently
expressed and was greeted with
hearty applause.
Few speakers have made a more
favorable impression at any of the
Commemoration exercises than did
President Falconer. Manly and dignified in bearing, clear cut and forcible in speech, and fluent in diction,
he went straight to the hearts of his
listeners. As by its fruit shall you
know the tree, so by its alumni shall
you guage the true calibre of a
university. Truth, great abiding
truth is the aim, and to it, absolute
fidelity is due. Sincerity of mind,
and simplicity of mind must characterize the student. Attention to detail must be jealously guarded, care
must be taken not to twist facts to
conform to theories, but to deduce
theories from facts. Man can be of
service when he has grasped some
The Univerguiding principle.
isty offers fellowship with great
men. True learning, with the conceptions of truth dominant will
give a moral conception which will
govern the world and the life and
spirit, so imbibed, will illumine and
enliven the civilization of the world.
Such were some of the splendid
thoughts expressed by Dr. Falconer.
Amidst college yells, Dr. Remsen was then introduced. He spoke
of the value of academic freedom
and showed the tendency toward the
application of the policy of protection, protection to "infant industries," in the heavy endowment of
institutions of learning. He voiced
a note of warning against the abuses
of endowment — the pauperizing of
the student by excessive distribution
of fellowships and scholarships, the
danger to the young investigator
from the foundation of institutes of
special research and investigation
which made no demands upon him
as a teacher and so deprived him of
one of the most potent guides to
clarity of thought and largeness of
view, and an even greater danger in
the demand of the community or the
government for his services in connection with undertakings, official
and semi-official, that absorbed his
time and his energies to the disadvantage of the institution where his
vocation lay.
Calls for (the) "Keyser" accompanied by an occasioned "Hoch der
Kaiser," were confusing to his Excellency, Count Bernstoff, until the
president of the Board of Trustees
rose to make a few impromptu re-

marks. Mr. Keyser informed the
alumni that he greeted with earnest
approval the evidence shown by them
in their Alma Mater and in the efforts being made at the present time
by the Trustees to fulfill the conditions
imposed by the General Education
Board upon their offer of $250,000
to the Johns Hopkins University.
They looked to the Alumni to assist them in this undertaking and be
considered it their duty to do all in
their power to aid and benefit their
Alma Mater. To this end he extended a warm and cordial welcome
to the Alumni Council to co-operate
and to rouse others to co-operate in
the great task.
Dr. Elgin R. L. Gould, chairman
of the Committee on Endowment of
the Alumni Council, and so representing that body on this occasion,
was the next speaker, and he spoke
with enthusiasm and effect from the
standpoint of the alumni. He said
that academic discussion of the best
methods of raising funds was a futile waste of time, and that abstract
preparations for an endowment campaign should cease. Men are not
persuaded to give money by logical
arguments carefully drawn up and
nicely expressed. They respond only to enthusiasm, to a spirit of emulation, and of friendly rivalry. Once
get men giving and others will give.
Get the ball started and it will continue to roll. For his part he stood
ready to co-operate and to do his
best to pay a share of the debt he
owed the University for what he had
received here as a graduate student
and as a holder of a fellowship. To
do the work effectively, in his opinion, it was necessary to divide up
the attacking forces, to "differentiate" the objects sought for, to separate into committees with some specific purpose before each of a nature to appeal to the individual approached. Let there be a "Rowland
Fund" for the advancement of the
study of physics, a Gilman memorial
housing those interests that Dr. Gilman had especially at heart, and other similar definite purposes for which
money is to be collected. As far as
he was concerned a Gilman Fund
would be that which he would specially like to raise. His advocacy
of this program aroused the interest
and approval of the Alumni who
shared his belief that with its adoption the work could be speedily and
successfully accomplished.
Last came the representative of the
Bachelors of Arts, Mr. Newton D.
Baker, City Solicitor of Cleveland,
one of the earnest co-operators with

Price, 5 cents per copy.
Mayor Tom Johnson and one of his
most effective lieutenants. Mr. Baker spoke with all the zeal of a
special pleader, with great clearness
of voice and a ringing tone of conviction. He was puzzled, he said, to
note how perplexing was the question of how to raise money for the
Johns Hopkins University. In the
Middle West financial support was
always so spontaneously given, that
he found it hard to appreciate the
difficulties with which we seemed to
find ourselves confronted. However,
in one instance he did recall that
the bounty of a benefactor had a
string attached to it—$150,000 was
offered, provided $35o,000 was raised
by a certain time. The trustees
worked and worked, until on the afternoon of the fateful day, when the
time expired for complying with the
conditions, they found themselves
till short by $20,000 of the necessary amount. The institution to be
benefited being theological in character, the trustees determined to have
recourse to prayer. 'Twas 7 p.m.
They prayed and prayed, until finally,
five minutes before midnight, one
from their midst arose and said,
"Brethren, our prayer is answered;
I will give it myself." Mr. Baker
spoke at length upon the social conditions existing in the Middle West,
with an eloquence and understanding that held the attention of all
present. He declared that that section of the country, freed somewhat
today from the thraldom of corrupt
political despotism, was now seething
with socialistic doctrines and tendencies and that although much good
had been accomplished in the placing of healthful restrictions around
the employment of child labor, restrictions fundamental to the maintenance of a high standard of manhood in the country, and in the passing of other laws—still, mere law
was only a partial remedy, and the
only salvation lay in raising the
standard of men. Here was the opportunity and duty of the University. Turn out men that cannot
steal and lie, men whose prejudices
are softened in the presence of higher knowledge and broader experience, men to whom the search for
truth and belief in the truth are
higher than the business of feathering the nest and lining the pocket.
Let the University, in the words of
Calvin, receive us as wood and return us to the world fashioned as
arrows to pierce the fallacies that
are constantly menacing our personal and national welfare.
It was a splendid reunion. May

THE NEWS-LETTER. March 7, 1910.
SECOND

MEDICAL REUNION

Letters From Drs. Welch and
Osler.
The following letter from Dr.
Welch has been received:
"Our faculty and all interested in
the future of the Johns Hopkins
Medical School must welcome cordially the proposal to form an association of our medical alumni. Such
an organization will be of great service to the school and think also of
benefit to our graduates. It will enable us here to maintain closer relations with our graduates, it will
cultivate a spirit of loyalty, it will
afford opportunity for agreeable and
profitable reunion here and elsewhere
in the country, and will strengthen
ties of friendship and helpful relations. The Johns Hopkins Medical
School has been enabled to advance
the cause of higher medical education and to establish standards which
are distinctive, and the reasons for
such an organization as that contemplated are perhaps even stronger
than in the case of other medical
schools, which have profited so much
by similar alumni associations.
With best wishes for the success
of the efforts of those engaged in
forming the organization and assurance of the heartiest co-operation on
the part of all connected with the
school, I am
Yours sincerely,
William H. Welch."
Dr. Osler says in lis letter to one
of the Council, "It would help the
school immensely to feel that the
graduates were in close touch and
their advice should be sought in certain matters. A great many of them
are now in positions from which
they recognize the lines of development along which a school like the
Johns Hopkins should take. A large
influental body of graduate opinion
keeps faculty and trustees up to the
mark. Recent appointments indicate
that the proper spirit is maintained,
but institutions, like individuals, have
their periods of ill-health,when things
do not go well and it is at just this
emergency that the graduate body is
most helpful."
We feel that all graduates of the
medical school will follow the counsel of our distinguished teachers and
do their utmost to make the organization of our alumni worthy of the
undergraduate school we represent.
Plans for the reunion are well under way. Whether or not it is desirable for the graduates of the
Medical School to form a permanent alumni organization is a question that ought to be considered
carefully from the point of view of
the Alumni Association as a whole.
Certainly no step will be taken that
is likely to prevent the Alumni Association from receiving the full
support of the Medical Alumni.

THE HOPKINS CLUB
Fi on, the beginning of the University, there was felt the need of a social center which found expression
in various ways. The Club that used
to meet in Little Garden St., filled
this want and, begun and continued
after • a German model, satisfied the
craving for companionship and intercourse which finally materialized
in the present University Club. As
this enlarged its scope, however, it
lost its character as a Hopkins Institution, and the call for such an organization became more and more urgent. This was recognized in 1899,
when a circular letter was sent to
!hose interested in such a project
suggesting the formation of an exclusively Hopkins Institution. This
appeal was signed by the following
gentlemen: J. S. Ames, R. Garret,
A. J. Shriver, W. Newcomer, J. H.
Hollander, G. G. Morrison, V. A.
Renouf, and H. B. Adams. The response was immediate, and the present Johns
Hopkins Club
was
successfully inaugurated. After some
years of useful existence, there
was a lapse of vitality and efficiency, which seemed to some
of the gentlemen interested to
be caused by the lack of adequate
accommodation, and largely through
the efforts of Mr. W. H. Buckler, one
of the trustees of the University, the
house at 227 W. Monument St., was
purchased, a home that was admirably fitted for the purpose in mind.
This was in 1905, and since then,
the Club has enjoyed a new era of
prosperity. Under the present direction it has broadened its outlook,
and enlarged its usefulness in many
directions, keeping strictly, however,
within its lines as an exclusively University movement. In its present
form it responds to a distinct demand, and has taken a place in the
University life held by no other of
the University Clubs or Associations.
It was felt that Hopkins men
should have a rallying point after
immediate
with
connection
the University had ceased, that
there should be a centre for the
alumni, where committees on business connected with the University
could meet, where dinners and reunions could be given, where gradu-ite-students could find pleasant quarters, where alumni living at a distance could find pleasant accommoda'ions and friends when called to the
city, rand this the Johns Hopkins
Club aims to furnish to its members.
At present the Alumni Association
has no quarters, and all records
change hands .and home with the
change of officers. It has been strongly recommended that it would be much
more satisfactory for the Association
to take a suitable room at the Johns
Hopkins Club-house where all the
records should be kept permanently,
such as a card catalogue of the members of the Association at large, and
of all branch associations, the Hop1,7:ns publications, and other Univervi'y matter, of interest to the Alumni.
Moreover, as it does not seem possi-

ble at present for the Alumni Council to be provided with proper quarters in the University buildings, they
could find a permanent Committeeroom in the Club-house which would
be assured to them for their exclusive use, where meetings could be
held and material kept safely, undisturbed by other possible occupants.
With the conviction that the 'traditional inertia of Hopkins graduates
was rather a habit than a chronic
condition, the Club has always been
desirious of initiating or endorsing
any suggestion that will create or
promote an interest in the University movement.
By special arrangement,the members
of the Club are enabled to use the
Homewood Field and Tennis Courts
during the summer months when the
University is closed, and the House is
kept open at the same time for the
convenience of members. To take
the place of the open air exercise
during the winter, a special gymnasium class is formed and trained in
the University building. In time it
is the ambition of the Governors to
put up a house at Homewood containing a large common-room, bath
rooms, and all the conveniences and
comforts that members could demand, in such a building.
The increasing use of the house
at 227 Monument St. is a gratifying
comment on the necessity of such a
Club. At the smokers, held every
Saturday evening, there is an attendance of from twenty-five to fifty men, and at the Field-Nights,
once a month, the number swells to a
hundred or more. The point which
the present administration of the
Club has been careful to insist on in
every way, and on every possible
occasion, is that the Club is working
hand and glove with the other University organizations, with the Alumni Council, with the Alumni Association, and with the various Department Clubs in order to show that
the aim for which all are striving is
the best welfare of the University,
and that the only question is what
means should he ' adopted to gain
this end most successfully.
After the Commemoration exercises, President Remsen announced the
names of the successful candidates
for the Alumni Council; these were
as follows:
Dr. Thomas S. Baker, from the
Ph.D. Group;
Dr. Thomas R. Brown, from the
M.D. Group.;
Mr. B. Howell Griswold, Jr., from
the A.B. Group.
Dr. St. George L. Sioussat, from
the At-Large Group.
Interest in the election has been
widespread, as ballots have come
from all parts of the country.. All
of the successful candidates, except
Dr. Sioussat, are at present members
of the Council. Dr. Sioussat, A.B.
1896, Ph.D. 1909, one of the most
prominent of our younger graduates,
is Professor of History and Dean
of the University of the South.

3.
ALUMNI

ASSOCIATION

The annual meeting of tile Alumni Association, held February 22, in
the Donovan Room, McCoy Hall, immediately after the close of the commemoration exercises, was well attended. The President of the Association, Dr. J. Whitridge Williams,
presided.
After considerable discussion, the
term of the president was extended
from one to two years. Since the
president of the Association is ex
officio a member of the Alumni Council, the other members of whicn
serve four years, it was thought advisable to lengthen the term of the
president of the Association so that
he would have time to become familiar with the workings of the
Council and be able to accomplisn
considerable work before his term on
the Council Board should expire.
The balloting for officers of the
Association, which had been begun
by mail, was concluded, with the result that the following were elected:
President, J. Whitridge Williams;
secretary, Wm. Sherman Bansemer ;
treasurer, Horace E. Flack; members
of Executive Committee to serve for
two years—Edward C. Armstrong,
Randolph Barton, Jr., George Stewart Brown, Alfred R. L. Dohme, Reid
Hunt.
Of these, only Dr. Williams and
Dr. Flack succeeded themselves. Mr.
Williams S. Bansemer, A.B. 1894.,
the newly elected secretary, is an attorney at law in Baltimore city, with
offices at 601 Maryland Telephone
Building, Baltimore, The ten members of the Executive Committee
hold office for two years, five being
elected every year. Of the five successful candidates, Dr. Armstrong'
and Dr. Hunt are professors in the
Johns Hopkins University, Dr.Dohme
is a wholesale druggist, and Mr. Barton and Mr. Brown are lawyers.
The Alumni Association is growing.
During the past ten years,
while Mr. Alfred J. Shriver was
secretary of the ,Association, the
membership increased from less than
fifty to nearly six hundred. This increase was due mainly to his efforts.
The report of the acting secretary,
Dr. Flack, showed good results coming from the campaign for increased
membership of the Association. During the past month nearly two hundred members have been secured.
There is every reason to believe that
the members of the Association,
as the result of the interest now
being displayed, and of the efforts
being made,will increase until it shall
become substantially co-extensive
with the list of the former students
of the University. If this can be done
the power for good of the University
would be tremendous.

Association for useful work and influence. through its Boards and
through the Alumni Council, for the

VOL. XIV. No. 18.
THE ALUMNI BANQUET
The annual alumni banquet of
1910, held on the evening of the
22nd, at the Hotel Beivedeit has
c.orne and gone,as far as the beautiful
ecorations and flowers and delicious menu, provided by the Committee, Messrs. Williams, Ogden and
Abercrombie, are L oncerned, and
many were the expressions of appreciation and pleasure heard from
the nearly two hundred alumni and
their guests assembled together on
that delightful occasion.
But in the spirit of fellowship
manifested and engendered and in
the feeling of enthusiasm created by
the eloquent addresses, the banquet
of 1910 will always live among those
fortunate enough to be present. How
one feels the inspiration of association, at a gattiering like this! How
forcibly .do such reunions impress up'On one the inestimable value of daily
intercourse among the students, the
living together within the same
Walls, the sleeping under the same
roofs! Only under such conditions
With such relations of daily life can
the influence of our Alma Mater be
forcibly realized; and for the accomplishment of this end we have
That
but one goal—Homewood.
University
the
the establishment of
Upon this beautiful site is essential
znd vital to its welfare is undisputed. Some additional funds will be
necessary actually to move, but this
task accomplished and the University once there, Johns Hopkins will
be the recipient of ample endowments, ever increasing in number,
With which to pursue her splendid
Work in the field of education.
Many distinguished guests honored the alumni by their presence.
Among them were, his Excellency,
the German Ambassador, Count
Bernstoff, and Dr. Robert Falconer,
President of Toronto University,the
nrasor of the day at the morning exercises in McCoy Hall. His Excellency in his admirable address dwelt
O n the feeling of good fellowship and
friendly relations existing between
the German Empire aryl this country,
expressed the belief that the intercourse between the scientists and the
scholars of the Universities of the
two countries, Germany and the
Pnited States, were potent factors
In arousing and cementing such
feelings of good will. He spoke
the value
emphasis of
With
country
a
to
university
a
of
and pointed out how his government
turned to the different professors in
the various German universities for

Baltimore, Md., March 7, 1910.
the solution of many problems and
for settlement of the disturbing
questions of the day. The address
of Count Bernstoff was eloquently
expressed and was greeted with
hearty applause.
Few speakers have made a more
favorable impression at any of the
Commemoration exercises than did
President Falconer. Manly and dignified in bearing, clear cut and forcible in speech, and fluent in diction,
he went straight to the hearts of his
listeners. As by its fruit shall you
know the tree, so by its alumni shall
you guage the true calibre of a
university. Truth, great abiding
truth is the aim, and to it, absolute
fidelity is due. Sincerity of mind,
and simplicity of mind must characterize the student. Attention to detail must be jealously guarded, care
must be taken not to twist facts to
conform to theories, but to deduce
theories from facts. Man can be of
service when he has grasped some
The Univerguiding principle.
isty offers fellowship with great
men. True learning, with the conceptions of truth dominant will
give a moral conception which will
govern the world and the life and
spirit, so imbibed, will illumine and
enliven the civilization of the world.
Such were some of the splendid
thoughts expressed by Dr. Falconer.
Amidst college yells, Dr. Remsen was then introduced. He spoke
of the value of academic freedom
and showed the tendency toward the
application of the policy of protection, protection to "infant industries," in the heavy endowment of
institutions of learning. He voiced
a note of warning against the abuses
of endowment — the pauperizing of
the student by excessive distribution
of fellowships and scholarships, the
danger to the young investigator
from the foundation of institutes of
special research and investigation
which made no demands upon him
as a teacher and so deprived him of
one of the most potent guides to
clarity of thought and largeness of
view, and an even greater danger in
the demand of the community or the
government for his services in connection with undertakings, official
and semi-official, that absorbed his
time and his energies to the disadvantage of the institution where his
vocation lay.
Calls for (the) "Keyser" accompanied by an occasioned "Hoch der
Kaiser," were confusing to his Excellency, Count Bernstoff, until the
president of the Board of Trustees
rose to make a few impromptu re-

marks. Mr. Keyser informed the
alumni that he greeted with earnest
approval the evidence shown by them
in their Alma Mater and in the efforts being made at the present time
by the Trustees to fulfill the conditions
imposed by the General Education
Board upon their offer of $250,000
to the Johns Hopkins University.
They looked to the Alumni to assist them in this undertaking and be
considered it their duty to do all in
their power to aid and benefit their
Alma Mater. To this end he extended a warm and cordial welcome
to the Alumni Council to co-operate
and to rouse others to co-operate in
the great task.
Dr. Elgin R. L. Gould, chairman
of the Committee on Endowment of
the Alumni Council, and so representing that body on this occasion,
was the next speaker, and he spoke
with enthusiasm and effect from the
standpoint of the alumni. He said
that academic discussion of the best
methods of raising funds was a futile waste of time, and that abstract
preparations for an endowment campaign should cease. Men are not
persuaded to give money by logical
arguments carefully drawn up and
nicely expressed. They respond only to enthusiasm, to a spirit of emulation, and of friendly rivalry. Once
get men giving and others will give.
Get the ball started and it will continue to roll. For his part he stood
ready to co-operate and to do his
best to pay a share of the debt he
owed the University for what he had
received here as a graduate student
and as a holder of a fellowship. To
do the work effectively, in his opinion, it was necessary to divide up
the attacking forces, to "differentiate" the objects sought for, to separate into committees with some specific purpose before each of a nature to appeal to the individual approached. Let there be a "Rowland
Fund" for the advancement of the
study of physics, a Gilman memorial
housing those interests that Dr. Gilman had especially at heart, and other similar definite purposes for which
money is to be collected. As far as
he was concerned a Gilman Fund
would be that which he would specially like to raise. His advocacy
of this program aroused the interest
and approval of the Alumni who
shared his belief that with its adoption the work could be speedily and
successfully accomplished.
Last came the representative of the
Bachelors of Arts, Mr. Newton D.
Baker, City Solicitor of Cleveland,
one of the earnest co-operators with

Price, 5 cents per copy.
Mayor Tom Johnson and one of his
most effective lieutenants. Mr. Baker spoke with all the zeal of a
special pleader, with great clearness
of voice and a ringing tone of conviction. He was puzzled, he said, to
note how perplexing was the question of how to raise money for the
Johns Hopkins University. In the
Middle West financial support was
always so spontaneously given, that
he found it hard to appreciate the
difficulties with which we seemed to
find ourselves confronted. However,
in one instance he did recall that
the bounty of a benefactor had a
string attached to it—$150,000 was
offered, provided $35o,000 was raised
by a certain time. The trustees
worked and worked, until on the afternoon of the fateful day, when the
time expired for complying with the
conditions, they found themselves
till short by $20,000 of the necessary amount. The institution to be
benefited being theological in character, the trustees determined to have
recourse to prayer. 'Twas 7 p.m.
They prayed and prayed, until finally,
five minutes before midnight, one
from their midst arose and said,
"Brethren, our prayer is answered;
I will give it myself." Mr. Baker
spoke at length upon the social conditions existing in the Middle West,
with an eloquence and understanding that held the attention of all
present. He declared that that section of the country, freed somewhat
today from the thraldom of corrupt
political despotism, was now seething
with socialistic doctrines and tendencies and that although much good
had been accomplished in the placing of healthful restrictions around
the employment of child labor, restrictions fundamental to the maintenance of a high standard of manhood in the country, and in the passing of other laws—still, mere law
was only a partial remedy, and the
only salvation lay in raising the
standard of men. Here was the opportunity and duty of the University. Turn out men that cannot
steal and lie, men whose prejudices
are softened in the presence of higher knowledge and broader experience, men to whom the search for
truth and belief in the truth are
higher than the business of feathering the nest and lining the pocket.
Let the University, in the words of
Calvin, receive us as wood and return us to the world fashioned as
arrows to pierce the fallacies that
are constantly menacing our personal and national welfare.
It was a splendid reunion. May

THE NEWS-LETTER. March 7, 1910.
SECOND

MEDICAL REUNION

Letters From Drs. Welch and
Osler.
The following letter from Dr.
Welch has been received:
"Our faculty and all interested in
the future of the Johns Hopkins
Medical School must welcome cordially the proposal to form an association of our medical alumni. Such
an organization will be of great service to the school and think also of
benefit to our graduates. It will enable us here to maintain closer relations with our graduates, it will
cultivate a spirit of loyalty, it will
afford opportunity for agreeable and
profitable reunion here and elsewhere
in the country, and will strengthen
ties of friendship and helpful relations. The Johns Hopkins Medical
School has been enabled to advance
the cause of higher medical education and to establish standards which
are distinctive, and the reasons for
such an organization as that contemplated are perhaps even stronger
than in the case of other medical
schools, which have profited so much
by similar alumni associations.
With best wishes for the success
of the efforts of those engaged in
forming the organization and assurance of the heartiest co-operation on
the part of all connected with the
school, I am
Yours sincerely,
William H. Welch."
Dr. Osler says in lis letter to one
of the Council, "It would help the
school immensely to feel that the
graduates were in close touch and
their advice should be sought in certain matters. A great many of them
are now in positions from which
they recognize the lines of development along which a school like the
Johns Hopkins should take. A large
influental body of graduate opinion
keeps faculty and trustees up to the
mark. Recent appointments indicate
that the proper spirit is maintained,
but institutions, like individuals, have
their periods of ill-health,when things
do not go well and it is at just this
emergency that the graduate body is
most helpful."
We feel that all graduates of the
medical school will follow the counsel of our distinguished teachers and
do their utmost to make the organization of our alumni worthy of the
undergraduate school we represent.
Plans for the reunion are well under way. Whether or not it is desirable for the graduates of the
Medical School to form a permanent alumni organization is a question that ought to be considered
carefully from the point of view of
the Alumni Association as a whole.
Certainly no step will be taken that
is likely to prevent the Alumni Association from receiving the full
support of the Medical Alumni.

THE HOPKINS CLUB
Fi on, the beginning of the University, there was felt the need of a social center which found expression
in various ways. The Club that used
to meet in Little Garden St., filled
this want and, begun and continued
after • a German model, satisfied the
craving for companionship and intercourse which finally materialized
in the present University Club. As
this enlarged its scope, however, it
lost its character as a Hopkins Institution, and the call for such an organization became more and more urgent. This was recognized in 1899,
when a circular letter was sent to
!hose interested in such a project
suggesting the formation of an exclusively Hopkins Institution. This
appeal was signed by the following
gentlemen: J. S. Ames, R. Garret,
A. J. Shriver, W. Newcomer, J. H.
Hollander, G. G. Morrison, V. A.
Renouf, and H. B. Adams. The response was immediate, and the present Johns
Hopkins Club
was
successfully inaugurated. After some
years of useful existence, there
was a lapse of vitality and efficiency, which seemed to some
of the gentlemen interested to
be caused by the lack of adequate
accommodation, and largely through
the efforts of Mr. W. H. Buckler, one
of the trustees of the University, the
house at 227 W. Monument St., was
purchased, a home that was admirably fitted for the purpose in mind.
This was in 1905, and since then,
the Club has enjoyed a new era of
prosperity. Under the present direction it has broadened its outlook,
and enlarged its usefulness in many
directions, keeping strictly, however,
within its lines as an exclusively University movement. In its present
form it responds to a distinct demand, and has taken a place in the
University life held by no other of
the University Clubs or Associations.
It was felt that Hopkins men
should have a rallying point after
immediate
with
connection
the University had ceased, that
there should be a centre for the
alumni, where committees on business connected with the University
could meet, where dinners and reunions could be given, where gradu-ite-students could find pleasant quarters, where alumni living at a distance could find pleasant accommoda'ions and friends when called to the
city, rand this the Johns Hopkins
Club aims to furnish to its members.
At present the Alumni Association
has no quarters, and all records
change hands .and home with the
change of officers. It has been strongly recommended that it would be much
more satisfactory for the Association
to take a suitable room at the Johns
Hopkins Club-house where all the
records should be kept permanently,
such as a card catalogue of the members of the Association at large, and
of all branch associations, the Hop1,7:ns publications, and other Univervi'y matter, of interest to the Alumni.
Moreover, as it does not seem possi-

ble at present for the Alumni Council to be provided with proper quarters in the University buildings, they
could find a permanent Committeeroom in the Club-house which would
be assured to them for their exclusive use, where meetings could be
held and material kept safely, undisturbed by other possible occupants.
With the conviction that the 'traditional inertia of Hopkins graduates
was rather a habit than a chronic
condition, the Club has always been
desirious of initiating or endorsing
any suggestion that will create or
promote an interest in the University movement.
By special arrangement,the members
of the Club are enabled to use the
Homewood Field and Tennis Courts
during the summer months when the
University is closed, and the House is
kept open at the same time for the
convenience of members. To take
the place of the open air exercise
during the winter, a special gymnasium class is formed and trained in
the University building. In time it
is the ambition of the Governors to
put up a house at Homewood containing a large common-room, bath
rooms, and all the conveniences and
comforts that members could demand, in such a building.
The increasing use of the house
at 227 Monument St. is a gratifying
comment on the necessity of such a
Club. At the smokers, held every
Saturday evening, there is an attendance of from twenty-five to fifty men, and at the Field-Nights,
once a month, the number swells to a
hundred or more. The point which
the present administration of the
Club has been careful to insist on in
every way, and on every possible
occasion, is that the Club is working
hand and glove with the other University organizations, with the Alumni Council, with the Alumni Association, and with the various Department Clubs in order to show that
the aim for which all are striving is
the best welfare of the University,
and that the only question is what
means should he ' adopted to gain
this end most successfully.
After the Commemoration exercises, President Remsen announced the
names of the successful candidates
for the Alumni Council; these were
as follows:
Dr. Thomas S. Baker, from the
Ph.D. Group;
Dr. Thomas R. Brown, from the
M.D. Group.;
Mr. B. Howell Griswold, Jr., from
the A.B. Group.
Dr. St. George L. Sioussat, from
the At-Large Group.
Interest in the election has been
widespread, as ballots have come
from all parts of the country.. All
of the successful candidates, except
Dr. Sioussat, are at present members
of the Council. Dr. Sioussat, A.B.
1896, Ph.D. 1909, one of the most
prominent of our younger graduates,
is Professor of History and Dean
of the University of the South.

3.
ALUMNI

ASSOCIATION

The annual meeting of tile Alumni Association, held February 22, in
the Donovan Room, McCoy Hall, immediately after the close of the commemoration exercises, was well attended. The President of the Association, Dr. J. Whitridge Williams,
presided.
After considerable discussion, the
term of the president was extended
from one to two years. Since the
president of the Association is ex
officio a member of the Alumni Council, the other members of whicn
serve four years, it was thought advisable to lengthen the term of the
president of the Association so that
he would have time to become familiar with the workings of the
Council and be able to accomplisn
considerable work before his term on
the Council Board should expire.
The balloting for officers of the
Association, which had been begun
by mail, was concluded, with the result that the following were elected:
President, J. Whitridge Williams;
secretary, Wm. Sherman Bansemer ;
treasurer, Horace E. Flack; members
of Executive Committee to serve for
two years—Edward C. Armstrong,
Randolph Barton, Jr., George Stewart Brown, Alfred R. L. Dohme, Reid
Hunt.
Of these, only Dr. Williams and
Dr. Flack succeeded themselves. Mr.
Williams S. Bansemer, A.B. 1894.,
the newly elected secretary, is an attorney at law in Baltimore city, with
offices at 601 Maryland Telephone
Building, Baltimore, The ten members of the Executive Committee
hold office for two years, five being
elected every year. Of the five successful candidates, Dr. Armstrong'
and Dr. Hunt are professors in the
Johns Hopkins University, Dr.Dohme
is a wholesale druggist, and Mr. Barton and Mr. Brown are lawyers.
The Alumni Association is growing.
During the past ten years,
while Mr. Alfred J. Shriver was
secretary of the ,Association, the
membership increased from less than
fifty to nearly six hundred. This increase was due mainly to his efforts.
The report of the acting secretary,
Dr. Flack, showed good results coming from the campaign for increased
membership of the Association. During the past month nearly two hundred members have been secured.
There is every reason to believe that
the members of the Association,
as the result of the interest now
being displayed, and of the efforts
being made,will increase until it shall
become substantially co-extensive
with the list of the former students
of the University. If this can be done
the power for good of the University
would be tremendous.

The introduction of a SeniorJunior Society has been suggested
recently. At certain other colleges

function is: (I) To assist in shaping the policy of undergraduate
opinion. (2) To represent the unwhich

To have this society composed
solely of seniors appears to us to too
greatly restrict the membership; it is
doubtful if such a body can be truly representative of the undergraduates. It is to be remembered, however, that sophomores and freshmen
are scarcely sufficiently familiar
with University traditions to serve
on such a board. The Senior-Junior Society therefore seems a suitable
compromise. The introduction of
